explanation:
OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET - The macro/function is used to obtain 'sem' from the token. Its definition must be inspected to see whether it performs any pointer arithmetic, indexing, memcpy/memmove/memset or other string.h operations that could access memory out of bounds.

OS_impl_bin_sem_table - The concrete table object indexed by the macro. Knowing its size, layout and element count is necessary to check that the index/address computed by the macro cannot produce an out-of-bounds access.

OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t - The struct type of the table elements (the type of 'sem'). Its member types and layout are needed to confirm that accessing '&(sem->cv)' and '&(sem->id)' are valid and do not overlap or cause out-of-bounds operations. Also inspect its fields for any embedded arrays or string operations.

OS_object_token_t - The token type passed into OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. Its representation/size/contents determine how the token is translated to an index/address; this is required to verify no out-of-bounds index computation or string.h usage on token contents.

OS_ObjectIndexFromToken - This helper appears in the static call graph and is commonly used by object-table macros. Its implementation must be checked to ensure it does not call any string.h functions (memcpy/strcpy/etc.) or perform arithmetic that could index outside table bounds.

pthread_cond_destroy - The target calls this function. While it is not a string function, its behavior determines whether the function returns OS_SEM_FAILURE or OS_SUCCESS; include its prototype/contract to ensure no hidden string.h usage and to reason about subsequent cleanup ordering.

pthread_mutex_destroy - Same rationale as pthread_cond_destroy: include prototype/semantics to reason about safety of destroying sem->id and to check for any indirect memory operations.

pthread_cond_t and pthread_mutex_t - The concrete types of sem->cv and sem->id. Their sizes and internal layout may be relevant if OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t has packing/overlap issues or if the table storage is tight; also to rule out any embedded string operations.

OS_SEM_FAILURE and OS_SUCCESS - The return-code macros/constants used by the function. They are needed to interpret the control-flow and whether cleanup/unusable-state paths are reachable; needed to determine whether any code paths could leave partially cleaned memory that might be subject to later string.h calls.

Note: Also include any macros or helper functions referenced inside OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or OS_ObjectIndexFromToken when inspecting those definitions (they should be added as additional close symbols if found). The above symbols are the minimal set needed to determine whether this function or the immediate helpers perform or enable any string.h operations that could access memory out of bounds.
